responses:
I appreciate the information. A dull ache in the shoulder could be indicative of various conditions. To further narrow down the possibilities, have you noticed if the pain worsens at night or when you perform certain movements with your arm?

[Option 1: Pain worsens at night or with certain movements]

[Option 2: Pain doesn't worsen at night or with movements]. Choose any one or provide yours...

Treatment will depend on your symptoms and the length of time you have them. Your caregiver may want you to limit activity on your affected shoulder to decrease stress on the tendon. This may help prevent further damage, decrease pain, and promote tendon healing.

The primary treatment is resting the shoulder and, for minor tears and inflammation, applying ice packs. You may need to wear a sling to keep the shoulder from moving.

Anti-inflammatory medications may also be prescribed. As soon as pain decreases, physical therapy is usually started to help regain normal motion. If pain persists after several weeks, the physician may inject cortisone into the affected area.

Surgery: If you have a large tear in your rotator cuff, you may need surgery to repair the tear. Sometimes during this kind of surgery, doctors may remove a bone spur or calcium deposits.

The surgery may be performed as an open repair through a 6- to 10-centimeter incision, or as an arthroscopic repair with the aid of a small camera inserted through a smaller incision. An arthroscope is used to view the shoulder joint and confirm the presence of a tear. It can also remove any bone spurs that may be present in the shoulder area.

The arthroscopic procedures usually involve a 2-inch incision in the outer shoulder. During this time, the torn rotator edge may be reattached to the humerus with stitches.

Arthroplasty: Some long-standing shoulder muscle tears may contribute to the development of rotator cuff arthropathy, which can include severe arthritis. In such cases, your doctor may discuss with you more extensive surgical options, including partial shoulder replacement (hemiarthroplasty) or total shoulder replacement (prosthetic arthroplasty).

A unique treatment option now available involves the use of a reverse ball-and-socket prosthesis. This reverse shoulder prosthesis is most appropriate for people who have very difficult shoulder problems. These include having arthritis in the joint, along with extensive tears of multiple muscles and tendons (rotator cuff) that support the shoulder, or having extensive rotator cuff tears and a failed previous shoulder joint replacement.

Why do rotator cuff injuries happen?

Rotator Cuff Tear: A ripping of one or more of the tendons. Result when a sudden eccentric force is applied to the rotator cuff resulting in the failure of the tendon. Uncommon under the age of 40 but strains do occur. In the population over 40 years of age, supraspinatus tears occur and less commonly, infraspinatus tears. Tears in the subscapularis tendon are uncommon and are often the result of a shoulder dislocation.

Causes

Poor posture: When you slouch your neck and shoulders forward, the space where the rotator cuff muscles reside can become smaller. This can allow a muscle or tendon to become pinched under your shoulder bones, including your collarbone, especially during overhead activities, such as throwing.

Falling: Using your arm to break a fall or falling on your arm can bruise or tear a rotator cuff tendon or muscle.

Lifting or Pulling: Lifting an object that's too heavy, or doing so improperly (especially overhead), can strain or tear your tendons or muscles.

Pulling something, such as an archery bow of too heavy poundage, may cause an injury.

patterns: is rotator cuff tear surgery necessary
responses: You may be able to stop or reverse early rotator cuff damage without surgery. Try using rest, ice and heat, anti-inflammatory medicines, and physiotherapy. If you have symptoms that don't get better after 3 to 6 months, you may need surgery.

patterns: how are rotator cuff injury diagnosed
responses: To diagnose a rotator cuff tear, a doctor will take a medical history and perform a physical exam in which you will be asked to move your shoulder. You doctor will look at your range of motion and discuss the amount of pain you are having. Tests you may need include: X-ray to examine your shoulder joint.

Rotator cuff tears may occur in two ways: A sudden acute tear may happen when you fall on your arm while it is stretched out. Or, it can occur after a sudden, jerking motion when you try to lift something heavy. A chronic tear of the rotator cuff tendon occurs slowly over time.

patterns: how are rotator cuff tears repaired
responses: To repair the rotator cuff: The tendons are re-attached to the bone. Small rivets (called suture anchors) are often used to help attach the tendon to the bone. The suture anchors can be made of metal or material that dissolves over time, and do not need to be removed.

patterns: are all rotator cuff injuries tears
responses: Rotator cuff injuries can range in severity from simple inflammation to complete tendon tears. The rotator cuff is a group of muscles and tendons that surround the shoulder joint, keeping the head of the upper arm bone firmly within the shallow socket of the shoulder.

patterns: does rotator cuff injury get better
responses: Rotator cuff tear treatment may include nonsurgical and surgical options. Rotator cuff tears don't heal on their own without surgery, but many people can improve functionally and decrease pain with nonsurgical treatment by strengthening their shoulder muscles.

patterns: is a sling good for a rotator cuff injury
responses: Using an arm sling to rest or immobilize your shoulder joint supports your arm while taking the pressure off your rotator cuff. Resting the soft connective tissues of your shoulder joint can relieve pain and promote healing. Limiting activities in which you reach overhead also reduces discomfort and encourages healing.

responses: Rotator cuff injuries are most often caused by progressive wear and tear of the tendon tissue over time. responses: The most typical sequelae of rotator cuff tears include shoulder pain with loss of strength and function. However, we noted anecdotally that a large proportion of patients presenting with rotator cuff injuries complained of numbness and/or tingling in their ipsilateral arm and hand.

responses: Rotator cuff syndrome can cause pain in your shoulders, neck, and more. Your rotator cuff is made up of four main muscles: the teres minor, subscapularis, infraspinatus, and supraspinatus. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the proper function of your shoulder.

patterns: can rotator cuff injury affect neck
responses: A weakness or tear in your rotator cuff can put tremendous stress on the secondary stabilizers. These overstressed stabilizers can cause neck strain or muscle spasms in your neck.

responses: The common symptom of acute rotator cuff tears, which usually go away after a period of time, include: Severe pain that originates from the upper area of your shoulder down toward the elbow.

responses: Boyle (1999) suggests that acute shoulder pain within the glenohumeral joint, often seen in impingement syndrome or rotator cuff pathology, may be the result of a sprain of the second rib articulation that compresses the second thoracic nerve and refers pain distally to the shoulder.

responses: Tendinopathy of the long head of the biceps (LHB) tendon commonly occurs in patients with rotator cuff tears, and the inflammation of one head tends to lead to inflammation of the other.

patterns: can rotator cuff injury cause forearm pain
responses: Can a rotator cuff injury cause pain in your arm and hand, too? Yes. Typically, the pain starts as a dull aching pain in your shoulder. As the injury progresses, it can cause radiating pain down the arm and into your hands.

patterns: What is a rotator cuff injury?
responses: A rotator cuff injury refers to damage or strain to the group of muscles and tendons that surround the shoulder joint, providing stability and enabling various shoulder movements.

A rotator cuff tear is a specific type of rotator cuff injury where one or more of the tendons connecting the rotator cuff muscles to the shoulder bone are partially or completely torn, causing pain, weakness, and limited shoulder motion.

patterns: What does a rotator cuff injury feel like?
responses: A rotator cuff injury often causes pain in the shoulder area, especially when lifting the arm or reaching overhead. There might be weakness, aching, and restricted range of motion in the affected shoulder.

patterns: What's a rotator cuff injury feel like?
responses: A rotator cuff injury often leads to pain, weakness, and limited movement in the shoulder. Pain is typically felt when raising the arm or performing activities involving the shoulder.

patterns: What does a rotator cuff injury look like?
responses: Externally, a rotator cuff injury might not be visibly obvious. There could be swelling or tenderness in the shoulder area. Imaging tests like MRI or ultrasound are often used to visualize the extent of the injury.

patterns: Which rotator cuff muscle is injured?
responses: A rotator cuff injury can involve any of the four muscles: supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis, which together make up the rotator cuff group.

patterns: Is a rotator cuff injury common?
responses: Yes, rotator cuff injuries are relatively common, especially as people age. They can result from overuse, trauma, or degeneration of the tendons over time.
Notable individuals like professional athletes often experience rotator cuff injuries. For example, baseball pitchers are prone to these injuries due to the repetitive throwing motion.

patterns: What kind of doctor treats rotator cuff injury?
responses: Orthopedic surgeons or sports medicine doctors often treat rotator cuff injuries. Physical therapists also play a crucial role in rehabilitation.

patterns: What part of the rotator cuff is most frequently injured?
responses: The supraspinatus muscle and tendon of the rotator cuff are the most frequently injured components. It is located on the top of the shoulder blade and helps lift the arm.

patterns: why are rotator cuff injuries common
responses: Rotator cuff injuries are common because the tendons in the rotator cuff are subject to a lot of wear and tear. They are also prone to injury from overhead activities, falls, and repetitive use.

patterns: why does rotator cuff tear hurt at night
responses: Rotator cuff tears can hurt at night because the shoulder joint is more relaxed when you are sleeping. This can put more stress on the tendons and make the pain worse.

patterns: why does rotator cuff tear hurt
responses: Rotator cuff tears can hurt because the tendons are no longer able to properly stabilize the shoulder joint. This can cause pain with movement, weakness, and instability.

patterns: does rotator cuff injury get better
responses: Rotator cuff injuries can get better with rest, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery. The severity of the tear and the patient's age and overall health will affect the chances of recovery.

patterns: how does your rotator cuff get injured
responses: Your rotator cuff can get injured by overuse, injury, or aging. Overuse injuries can happen from repetitive overhead activities, such as swimming or tennis. Injury can happen from a fall or a sudden movement. Aging can weaken the tendons in the rotator cuff, making them more prone to injury.

patterns: why is the rotator cuff prone to injury
responses: The rotator cuff is prone to injury because it is subject to a lot of wear and tear. The tendons in the rotator cuff are also relatively thin and weak, making them more susceptible to tearing. Additionally, the shoulder joint is a complex joint that is prone to instability, which can put more stress on the rotator cuff tendons.

patterns: will rotator cuff injury heal on its own
responses: Minor rotator cuff injuries may heal on their own with rest and conservative treatment, but more severe injuries might require medical intervention.

patterns: will rotator cuff injury heal itself
responses: Rotator cuff injuries may heal on their own, especially if they are minor. However, some cases might need medical attention for proper healing.

patterns: will rotator cuff injury show on x ray
responses: Rotator cuff injuries might not be visible on X-rays, as they primarily involve soft tissues like tendons and muscles. Other imaging techniques like MRI or ultrasound are more suitable for diagnosing such injuries.

patterns: can rotator cuff injury affect hand
responses: A rotator cuff injury typically affects the shoulder and arm. While it might indirectly impact hand movement due to reduced shoulder function, it doesn't usually directly cause hand symptoms.

patterns: can rotator cuff injury cause breast pain
responses: Rotator cuff injuries are not likely to cause breast pain. Breast pain could be due to various other factors, and if you're experiencing breast pain, it's important to consult a medical professional.

patterns: can rotator cuff injury cause chest pain
responses: Rotator cuff injuries usually don't cause chest pain. If you're experiencing chest pain, it's crucial to seek medical attention, as it could be related to a different and potentially serious issue.

patterns: can rotator cuff injury cause neck pain
responses: Rotator cuff injuries can sometimes lead to neck pain, especially if they cause you to change your posture or movement patterns. However, neck pain could also be attributed to other factors, so a proper medical assessment is recommended.

patterns: can rotator cuff injury cause numbness and tingling
responses: Rotator cuff injuries might lead to numbness and tingling if they impinge on nerves in the shoulder area. It's important to consult a healthcare professional to determine the exact cause of these symptoms.

responses: Rotator cuff injuries could potentially lead to tingling in the fingers if they affect the nerves connected to the shoulder and arm. Consulting a medical professional can help determine the cause of the symptoms.

patterns: does rotator cuff tear require surgery
responses: Not all rotator cuff tears require surgery. Minor tears or injuries might respond to conservative treatments like rest, physical therapy, and medication. However, larger or more severe tears might necessitate surgical intervention.
